history.content: None of these classes are equivalent to each other; at best, they are analogous. That being said, if you take all the ieor and stats classes you have mentioned, I would strongly suggest not taking either 126 or 127. While you won't know every single bit of content from these two classes from your other coursework, there will be substantial overlap to the point where you can teach yourself the remaining content, which to reiterate, would not be a huge portion of either class. Hope that helps!

children.subject:
Hey Parth,

To me, "equivalent" suggests that one covers all the same content, while "analogous" suggests (again, to me) that the classes cover the same niche, but aren't identical to each other. I've often seen people here discussing classes across different departments as subsets of one another, which is rarely, if ever, the case. "analogous" and "equivalent" are definitely similar in the scope, and in most cases I would agree you can use the words interchangeably; in this particular case, I make the distinction because I want to make the point that one will not cover the *exact* same content of 126 as you do in 134, 165, and 173, (which would make them equivalent) but one will cover enough that the remaining material can be self taught (which would make them analogous). Hope that helps!

Regarding "My understanding is that taking all of those IEOR classes after the EECS ones would be very repetitive in content and not worth your time."

I definitely agree with you there, but I think OP is saying they're taking all the IEOR classes anyway, and is asking if they should take 126 and 127 or not. If I'm wrong about that, please correct me @Parth/OP

op here, thank you both for your advice! yeah, i'll have to take all these ieor courses for my other major, but was wondering if i should also take eecs 126/7 - i appreciate your input, thank you both so much :-)

Looking at the IEOR requirements, it seems to be an entire major in "pre-ML," even to the point where if you take the ML IEOR class, you might actually be better prepared for an ML PhD than most EECS majors are. Probability theory, stochastic processes, and optimization are definitely a part of EECS, but it seems like these three things are the fundamentals of industrial engineering.

Can anyone tell me why EECS/CS/DS tend to be the go-to machine learning and data analytics majors when IEOR seems so much more better tailored?

Well, there's a couple reasons. The most likely reason is that IEOR is literally "Industrial Engineering and Operations Research" which doesn't carry the same connotation as doing CS/EECS. In addition, I'm sure the vast majority of people who end up doing a PhD in ML don't come in with that as their goal - the (EE)CS major is much broader and covers a lot more ground (UX design, Embedded systems, etc) so for someone who likes this material but doesn't have much experience, the average freshman college student, (EE)CS is a much better bet. Lastly, although the classes cover the same material mathematically, the CS variants would probably take a more CS centric approach, which lends itself better to a PhD in CS than the industrial engineering centric approach.

Ishaan, can you define "analogous" and "equivalent" because I'm honestly a little confused how those are different?

My understanding is that taking all of those IEOR classes after the EECS ones would be very repetitive in content and not worth your time.

history.content:
i'm double majoring in ieor so i'm taking some ieor/stats courses and was wondering if it'd be worth it to take the following eecs classes:

  • eecs 126 - would stat 134 (probability), ieor 165 (statistics, also the ieor equivalent of stat 135), and ieor 173 (stochastic processes) be equivalent?
  • eecs 127 - would ieor 160 (nonlinear and discrete optimization) and 162 (linear programming and network flows) be equivalent?

i'll definitely need to take all these ieor courses for my ieor major, but i'm not sure if it'd be repetitive to take eecs 126 and 127 - i'd like to avoid repeating classes - any thoughts would be really appreciated!
history.subject: ieor equivalents of eecs classes
